channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israeli Military Takes Responsibility for Strike That Killed 7 Aid Workers
item.description: The killings were “a grave mistake,” the Israeli military chief of staff said in an unusually direct acknowledgment of fault. The strike prompted aid agencies to reassess their operations in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Inspecting a vehicle that World Central Kitchen workers were in when they were killed in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli Army Withdraws From Major Gaza Hospital, Leaving Behind a Wasteland
item.description: Al-Shifa Hospital lies in ruins after a battle there between Israeli soldiers and Gazan gunmen. Shortly before withdrawing, the Israeli military brought journalists from The Times to witness the damage.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: Strong Taiwan Quake Kills 9, Injures Hundreds
item.description: The earthquake was the most powerful to hit the island in 25 years. Dozens of people remained trapped, and many buildings were damaged, with the worst centered in the city of Hualien.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: The Taiwan Earthquake’s Aftermath
item.description: See scenes from around the island.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A search and rescue team in front of a building in the city of Hualien.

item.title: How European Soccer Made Peace With Fasting During Ramadan
item.description: In competitions like the Premier League, Muslim pros who once faced pressure to avoid daily fasts during the monthlong holiday now benefit from custom diets and in-game breaks.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Everton’s Muslim players broke their fast during a prearranged pause in their Premier League match at Newcastle on Tuesday.

item.title: Inside an English Village Scarred by A High-Speed Railway, HS2
item.description: When Britain cut back a planned high-speed rail line, some residents on the route were pleased. They’re less delighted with what happened next.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 50 homes in the area have stood empty for two years or more, campaigners say — years during which HS2’s ambitions shrank markedly.

item.title: Zelensky Lowers Draft Age for Ukraine’s Depleted Army
item.description: The idea of requiring more men to join the fight against Russia’s invasion has become toxic politically, but Russia is not relenting in its assault.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training in the country’s Donetsk region on Monday.

item.title: ‘The Russian Language Is Everywhere Again’: Exiles Cause Unease in Lithuania
item.description: An influx of exiled Russian activists and refugees from Ukraine and Belarus is stirring fears in a country that fought to preserve its language and culture under Soviet occupation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Tomas Dapkus
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vilnius has become a center of the Russian political opposition.

item.title: Ugandan Court Upholds Draconian Anti-Gay Law
item.description: The law, which includes the death penalty as a punishment in some cases, has been strongly condemned, including by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Uganda’s Constitutional Court during a hearing of the petitions challenging the contentious anti-gay law in December in Kampala, the capital.

item.title: Senegal President Bassirou Diomaye Faye Takes Office and Promises Change
item.description: Senegal’s new president, Bassirou Diomaye Faye, took the oath of office in Tuesday’s ceremony. Close behind him sat the popular opposition leader who had clinched the win.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Newly elected President Bassirou Diomaye Faye takes the oath of office as president during the inauguration ceremony in Dakar, on Tuesday.

item.title: Fire at Masquerade Nightclub in Istanbul Kills 29
item.description: The fire took place at Masquerade, a popular club that was closed to the public and undergoing renovations. Six people were arrested.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene of a fire in a nightclub on Tuesday in Istanbul.

item.title: Rome’s Future Is a Walk Through Its Past
item.description: City officials kicked off a new project to create a monumental, pedestrian-friendly, archaeological area downtown, but some critics worry the plans puts tourists before residents.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Tourists outside of the Colosseum in Rome on Saturday. City leaders have proposed a new, pedestrian-friendly area in the center of the city, which supporters say would promote ancient Roman history.

item.title: Adidas Stops Customization of Germany Jersey for Fear of Nazi Symbolism
item.description: The apparel giant moved quickly to block the sale of shirts bearing the No. 44, which resembled a banned Nazi logo in the uniform’s new lettering.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Jonathan Tah, a German player wearing No. 4, in a match against France last month. The team is required to assign the Nos. 4 and 14 in major tournaments.

item.title: 5-Star Bird Houses for Picky but Precious Guests: Nesting Swiftlets
item.description: To lure swiftlets, whose saliva-built nests fetch high prices in China, people in Borneo compete to build them the most luxurious accommodations: safe, clean, dark and with pools for bathing.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
item.media:credit: Nyimas Laula for The New York Times
item.media:description: Not a prison nor a fortress, but a bird house on Borneo for swiftlets, whose nests fetch high prices in China.

item.title: Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquake in 25 Years Injures Hundreds
item.description: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by over 100 aftershocks. Dozens of people were trapped. Two buildings in the city of Hualien teetered perilously.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin, Victoria Kim, Chris Buckley, Mike Ives, Siyi Zhao and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Inflation Cools in Eurozone, Nearing Central Bank’s Target
item.description: Prices in the countries that use the euro rose 2.4 percent in the year through March, coming closer to the European Central Bank’s 2 percent inflation target.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: What We Know About the 7.4-Magnitude Earthquake in Taiwan
item.description: The quake set off aftershocks and damaged dozens of buildings, killing nine people and leaving many injured or trapped.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Taiwan’s Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A collapsed brick wall in a house after the earthquake in Taipei.

item.title: Hualien, on Taiwan’s Coast, Is Prone to Earthquakes
item.description: The area, known for a famous gorge and aquamarine waters, sits on several active faults.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ashley Pon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rice fields in Hualien County in 2021. The scenic area is one of the most sparsely populated parts of Taiwan.

item.title: Taiwan Quake Damages Buildings and a Highway in Hualien
item.description: Rescue efforts in the city were centered on two buildings, one of which appeared near collapse. Some roads to the region were cut off.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Paul Mozur, Meaghan Tobin and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A leaning building in Hualien, a city on the eastern coast of Taiwan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Seven aid workers killed in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: A car used by World Central Kitchen was hit by an Israeli strike in Deir al Balah, Gaza.

item.title: A Look at Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquakes
item.description: Earthquakes of similar intensity to the one that hit the island on Wednesday have caused large-scale death and destruction.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A 17-story apartment building that collapsed after an earthquake in Tainan, Taiwan, in 2016.

item.title: What We Know About the Iranian Commanders Killed by Israel in Syria
item.description: The leaders included Gen. Mohammad Reza Zahedi, the senior most leader in Iran’s armed forces assassinated since Qassim Suleimani was killed in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians Tuesday demonstrated against the Israeli strike that killed Iranian commanders in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Canadian Lawmaker Says China Had Chinese Students Vote for Him
item.description: Han Dong, a member of Parliament who is accused of benefiting from the Chinese government’s help, testified at a public hearing on foreign interference.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Rene Johnston/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Han Dong’s testimony was part of an ongoing federal inquiry into foreign meddling in Canada’s political system, especially the general elections of 2019 and 2021.

item.title: Protest Outside Netanyahu’s Home Turns Into ‘Riot,’ Israeli Police Say
item.description: Antigovernment demonstrators took to the streets for the third night in a row to call for early elections.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Some demonstrators tried to break through barriers near Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s house, the police said.

item.title: 7 Aid Workers Killed in Gaza Were Known for a Passion for Helping Others
item.description: Gaza has been the deadliest place for aid workers since the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Relatives and friends mourn the death of Saif Abu Taha, one of the seven workers with World Central Kitchen who was killed in Gaza when an aid convoy was fired on Monday night.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Aid Workers Killed in Gaza
item.description: Plus, President Biden talked to Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The aid workers were traveling in armored vehicles clearly marked with the World Central Kitchen logo.

item.title: Israel bombed an Iranian Embassy complex. Is that allowed?
item.description: Israel can likely argue that its actions did not violate international law’s protections for diplomatic missions, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: The aftermath of the strike on the Iranian Embassy complex on Tuesday in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Kill 7 Aid Workers in Gaza
item.description: The attack on clearly marked vehicles run by the World Central Kitchen shows how dangerous relief work has been during the war, and adds fuel to accusations that Israel has bombed indiscriminately.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: One of the vehicles that World Central Kitchen vehicles workers were traveling in when they were killed in an Israeli strike late on Monday in Deir al Balah, Gaza.

item.title: Protests Over Gaza Intensify at American Art Museums
item.description: A protest at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco led to the resignation of its leader and to a monthlong closure of its galleries.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Marc Tracy
item.category: Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel
Yerba Buena Center for the Arts

item.title: Fears Grow That Syria Strike Could Spur Retaliatory Attacks on Israel and U.S.
item.description: Current and former American officials say the airstrike on an Iranian embassy compound in Damascus was a serious blow to Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran on Monday condemning the Israeli strike that killed Iranian commanders in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Ukraine Drones Hit Oil Refinery and Factory Deep in Russia
item.description: Ukrainian media and analysts, and Russian officials, said Ukraine had carried out the attack some 700 miles from the land it controls. Ukraine’s military and intelligence forces declined to comment.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova

item.title: A Timeline of Iran and Israel’s Shadow War Across the Middle East
item.description: The regional rivals have for decades targeted each other’s interests, including with a recent strike in Syria that killed three Iranian commanders. Here are some other notable flash points.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Outside the Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: What We Know About the World Central Kitchen Strike Victims in Gaza
item.description: The group said one of the seven workers who was killed was a dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada, while the others were from Australia, Britain, Gaza and Poland.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The funeral of a Palestinian who worked as a driver and translator for World Central Kitchen, in Rafah on Tuesday.

item.title: Strike in Damascus Escalates Israel’s Undeclared War With Iran
item.description: Tehran promises major retaliation, and the danger of a miscalculation is ever-present. But neither side wants a major shooting war, given the stakes.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The Iranian Embassy building in Damascus, Syria, that was hit by an Israeli strike on Monday.

item.title: What We Know About the Strike That Killed World Central Kitchen Workers in Gaza
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel acknowledged on Tuesday a “tragic case of our forces unintentionally hitting innocent people.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A car used by World Central Kitchen that was hit by a strike in Deir al Balah in the central Gaza Strip.

item.title: Finland School Shooting: 12-Year-Old Suspect Detained After 1 Dead and 2 Injured
item.description: Another 12-year-old was killed and two other students were wounded in a country with one of the highest rates of gun ownership in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Police officers outside the school in Vantaa, Finland, after the shooting on Tuesday.

item.title: Gaza Aid Groups Fear for Safety After Strike on World Central Kitchen
item.description: “Gaza right now is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a humanitarian worker,” a spokeswoman for Save the Children said after a strike killed World Central Kitchen workers.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: U.N. staff members inspecting the remnants of a car used by World Central Kitchen in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Japan’s Emperor and Royal Family Join Instagram
item.description: No memes or spontaneity to see here, people. Just the usual official pictures of Emperor Naruhito and his family.
item.dc:creator: Kiuko Notoya and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Emperor Naruhito, center, with his family on the balcony of the Imperial Palace in Tokyo earlier this year.

item.title: José Andrés’s World Central Kitchen Feeds People in Disaster and War Zones
item.description: The group is a relatively new aid provider in Gaza, but it has garnered notice by making bold moves, like building a jetty out of rubble to bring aid in by sea.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Volunteers for World Central Kitchen preparing food for displaced Palestinians in Rafah, Gaza, last month.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Iran says Israel struck its generals in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike on a building close to the Iranian Consulate in Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: North Korea Tests Ballistic Missile That Could Reach Guam
item.description: The test, analysts said, may have involved a new intermediate-range hypersonic missile that is faster to launch and more difficult to intercept.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A news broadcast in Seoul on Tuesday with file footage of a North Korean missile launch.

item.title: Iran Says the Deadly Israeli Strike in Damascus Will Not Go Unanswered
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said Israel would be punished for the strike, which killed three top commanders.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters on Monday in Palestine Square in Tehran condemned the Israeli strike that killed Iranian commanders in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Backs J.K. Rowling in Criticism of New Scottish Hate Crime Law
item.description: The legislation expands protections and creates a new charge of “stirring up hatred.” Critics, including J.K. Rowling, said the law was “wide open to abuse.”
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Edinburgh, Scotland. A conviction under the country’s new hate crime law could lead to a fine and a prison sentence of up to seven years.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Iran Said Israel Killed Top Generals
item.description: Also, the U.S. could vote on aid to Ukraine in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The strike hit the Iranian consulate in Damascus, Syria.

item.title: Lou Conter, Last Survivor of the Battleship Arizona, Dies at 102
item.description: Escaping injury in the Japanese attack on the ship in Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, he went on to help in recovering bodies and putting out fires.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Lou Conter in 2015 during a memorial service in Honolulu marking the 74th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

item.title: Israeli Strike in Syria Kills 7, Including 3 Iranian Commanders
item.description: The airstrike on an Iranian Embassy building was one of the biggest attacks yet in a shadow war that has increasingly been moving into the open.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Hiba Yazbek and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The aftermath of the strike on an Iranian Embassy building in Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Will Shut Down Al Jazeera in Israel
item.description: The move came after Israeli lawmakers passed a new law that allows the government to temporarily shutter foreign media outlets deemed to be a risk to national security.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss
item.media:description: Officials indicated they would shut down Al Jazeera in Israel.

item.title: Netanyahu Faces Growing Pressure From All Sides
item.description: The prime minister is being pulled in opposing directions by his coalition partners, Israeli public opinion and allies abroad, with the war in Gaza and his political future in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A demonstrator against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Betty Cole Dukert, Top ‘Meet the Press’ Producer, Dies at 96
item.description: She worked as a secretary before being hired as an associate producer at the NBC News public affairs show in 1956. She went on to spend 41 years there.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Outside Israel’s Parliament, Protesters Explain Why Netanyahu Must Go
item.description: A tent camp is a temporary home for some of the thousands of Israelis who are mounting a four-day protest calling for early elections to oust the Israeli prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Tents of protesters camped outside of the Parliament building, the Knesset, in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: American YouTuber Freed After Kidnapping in Haiti
item.description: Adisson Pierre Maalouf, who is from Georgia, was kidnapped two weeks ago by a gang leader after traveling to Haiti.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Andre Paultre

item.title: Turkey’s Opposition Strikes Elections Blow to Erdogan’s Party
item.description: A raft of local election victories by rivals of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s governing party could serve as a check on his power.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Yavuz Ozden/Dia Images, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his wife, Emine Erdogan, at his party headquarters in Ankara, the Turkish capital, early Monday.

item.title: Cease-Fire Talks to Confront How Displaced Palestinians Can Return
item.description: Many Palestinians from northern Gaza are now sheltering in the south, but they want to return home.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians in Rafah, along the border with Egypt, on Saturday.

item.title: The Bizarre Chinese Murder Plot Behind Netflix’s ‘3 Body Problem’
item.description: Lin Qi, a billionaire who helped produce the science-fiction hit, was poisoned to death by a disgruntled executive. His attacker now faces the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Zhang Zhi/Red Star News/Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Lin Qi spent millions to buy the rights to a Chinese science-fiction novel called “The Three-Body Problem” but was murdered before it launched as a television series.

item.title: Israeli Soldiers Pull Out of Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital After 2-Week Battle
item.description: The soldiers left widespread devastation after battles with Palestinian militants in and around the Al-Shifa complex. “Now it looks like a wasteland,” a surgeon at the hospital said.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: A Palestinian woman sitting amid the rubble of Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital on Monday.

item.title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Opens in Japan, Earning $2.5 Million in First Three Days
item.description: While some viewers lamented the movie’s exclusion of scenes from Hiroshima or Nagasaki, others said they recognized that it had another story to tell.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: A poster for “Oppenheimer” in Tokyo on Friday. The movie opened in Japan eight months after its release in the United States.
